title: Who are your people when systems fail?
teaser: Democracy feels fragile. Safety nets are being cut. Who will you call when crises hit?

panels.heading: WHEN THE NETS BREAK
panels.content:
SNAP benefits are being cut. 4 million people will lose food assistance.

The

just passed. Housing subsidies reduced. Mental health funding slashed.

Democracy feels fragile—71% of Californians are dissatisfied with it. Political violence at 1970s levels. National Guard troops deployed to cities.

The institutions you thought would catch you are fraying.

Your therapist can't fix systemic failure. Your 401(k) can't buy community. Your government can't guarantee safety.

So when the safety nets break, who's left standing with you?

panels.heading: THE ILLUSION OF CONNECTION
panels.content:
You have people, right?

You have coworkers you grab coffee with. A gym buddy. A book club. 847 Instagram followers.

But here's the test: **Who knows what keeps you up at 3 AM?**

29% of people aged 30-44 are "frequently or always" lonely. That's not a failure. That's an epidemic.

You're surrounded by voices—notifications, headlines, small talk—but who knows the specific shape of your fear?

Who would you call if you lost your job tomorrow?

Who would bring you soup?

panels.heading: THE COST OF TRANSACTIONAL COMMUNITY
panels.content:
The cost of transactional community is this: **when you can't perform, you disappear.**

Your run club doesn't know you're depressed. Your happy hour friends don't know your marriage is failing. Your networking group doesn't know you're one paycheck from eviction.

Because those aren't communities. They're activity-based gatherings.

When the activity stops—injury, layoff, burnout—do they still show up?

Community built on what you DO collapses when you can't DO anymore.

You need people who know you when you're not performing.

The question is: do you have them?

panels.heading: AN ANCIENT COMMUNITY IN CRISIS
panels.content:
2,000 years ago, a group of people faced systemic collapse.

Roman occupation. Political violence. Economic exploitation. Government persecution.

The safety nets were gone.

So they built something else. Not a networking group. Not an activity club.

The text says:

**"All the believers were together and had everything in common. They sold property and possessions to give to anyone who had need."**

Not charity. **Mutual aid.**

Not transactions. **Covenant.**

panels.heading: THE KINGDOM ECONOMICS OF SHOWING UP
panels.content:
This wasn't socialism. This wasn't naive idealism.

This was **kingdom economics**: when institutions fail, God's people become the safety net for each other.

They didn't wait for the government to fix it. They shared what they had.

When one person lost their income, the community provided. When someone was sick, the community showed up. When systems collapsed, **the people of God were still standing.**

Not because they were rich or powerful.

Because they knew: **true community isn't built on what you do. It's built on whose you are.**

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I've been surrounded by people but still alone.

I've built networks, not community. Transactions, not covenant.

When the systems fail—and they are failing—I don't know who my people are.

Teach me what it means to belong. Not to a group, but to You. And through You, to each other.

Help me find the ones who would bring soup.

Amen.
